verses.text: The word of the LORD came to Jonah son of Amittai, saying,
verses.comment: Jonah is introduced as a prophet, connecting to his previous mention in 2 Kings. Note the motif of God directly commissioning His servants.

verses.text: "Arise, go to Nineveh, that great city, and cry out against it, for their evil has come up before Me."
verses.comment: Nineveh’s wickedness requires divine intervention. Similar themes recur about prophetic calls to repentance (cf. Isaiah, Nahum).

verses.text: But Jonah rose to flee to Tarshish from the presence of the LORD. He went down to Joppa and found a ship going to Tarshish. So he paid the fare and boarded, to go with them to Tarshish, away from the presence of the LORD.
verses.comment: Jonah attempts to evade God, yet Psalm 139 affirms that no one can truly escape God’s presence.

verses.text: Then the LORD hurled a great wind on the sea, and there was a mighty storm on the sea, so that the ship was nearly broken apart.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over creation is manifest here, foreshadowing Christ’s later authority over storms (cf. Luke 8).

verses.text: The sailors were afraid and each cried out to his own god. And they hurled the cargo that was in the ship into the sea to lighten it. But Jonah had gone down into the innermost part of the ship and was lying down, fast asleep.
verses.comment: Jonah’s sleep parallels Christ sleeping during the storm (Mark 4), subtly prefiguring Christ’s sacrifice and peace amid chaos.

verses.text: So the captain came and said to him, "How can you be asleep? Get up and call on your god! Maybe your god will care about us, so that we do not perish."
verses.comment: The captain's plea foreshadows humanity's universal need for salvation and the urgency to seek divine mercy.

verses.text: And they said to one another, "Come, let us cast lots, so we may know who is the cause of this evil upon us." So they cast lots, and the lot fell on Jonah.
verses.comment: Casting lots is a means for divine direction, as seen in Saul’s and the Apostles’ decisions. God’s providence orchestrates the outcome.

verses.text: Then they said to him, "Tell us, please, who is responsible for this disaster? What is your occupation, and where do you come from? What is your country, and of what people are you?"
verses.comment: Jonah is interrogated regarding his identity and purpose, echoing how witnesses must testify to truth under pressure.

verses.text: He said to them, "I am a Hebrew, and I fear the LORD, the God of heaven, who made the sea and the dry land."
verses.comment: Jonah's confession reveals faith in the Creator God, akin to the foundational professions later required of believers.

verses.text: Then the men were greatly afraid, and said to him, "What have you done?" For the men knew he was fleeing from the presence of the LORD, because he had told them.
verses.comment: Their fear reflects a proper reverence before God’s power; recognition of divine authority incites awe and repentance.

verses.text: Then they asked him, "What should we do to you so that the sea may quiet down for us?" For the sea grew more and more tempestuous.
verses.comment: Jonah here becomes a type of intercessor; effective remedy requires sacrifice, a theme continued in biblical revelation.

verses.text: He said to them, "Pick me up and throw me into the sea; then the sea will quiet down for you. For I know it is because of me that this great storm has come upon you."
verses.comment: Jonah’s acceptance of death for others directly prefigures Christ’s sacrificial death for the forgiveness of sins.

verses.text: Nevertheless, the men rowed hard to get back to land, but they could not, for the sea grew even wilder against them.
verses.comment: Human effort proves futile apart from submission to God’s will, a lesson in humble reliance.

verses.text: So they cried out to the LORD, "O LORD, let us not perish for this man’s life, and do not hold us guilty for innocent blood. For You, O LORD, have done as You pleased."
verses.comment: Gentiles petition for mercy, anticipating prayers for forgiveness and themes of substitution later fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: So they picked up Jonah and threw him into the sea, and the sea ceased from its raging.
verses.comment: Jonah’s descent calms the storm, mirroring the peace brought by Christ’s atoning sacrifice and authority over nature.

verses.text: Then the men feared the LORD greatly, and they offered a sacrifice to the LORD and made vows.
verses.comment: Non-Israelites worship the God of Israel through sacrifice and vows, foreshadowing the universal call to worship through ritual and covenantal commitment.

verses.text: And the LORD appointed a great fish to swallow Jonah, and Jonah was in the belly of the fish three days and three nights.
verses.comment: The ‘three days and three nights’ directly foreshadows Christ's burial and resurrection; Jonah as sign of salvation for all nations.
